lessonTitle: Additional Difficult Sounds: Trilled R and Gutturals

questions.question: Which sound is produced by vibrating the tongue against the alveolar ridge?
questions.explanation: რ [r] is the alveolar trill, produced by vibrating the tongue tip against the alveolar ridge. This is the 'rolled r' sound.

questions.question: What is the difference between ღ [ɣ] and ხ [x]?

options.text: ღ is voiced, ხ is voiceless
ხ is voiced, ღ is voiceless
One is ejective, one is not

questions.explanation: ღ [ɣ] is voiced (vocal cords vibrate), ხ [x] is voiceless (no vibration). Both are guttural fricatives made at the back of the throat.

exercises.title: Match Sounds to Their Descriptions
exercises.instructions: Match each sound with its correct description.

rightItems.text: Voiced guttural fricative - throat sound with vibration
Voiceless guttural fricative - throat sound without vibration

questions.explanation: რ [r] is the trilled r, ღ [ɣ] is voiced guttural (like clearing throat with voice), ხ [x] is voiceless guttural (like clearing throat without voice).

exercises.title: Pronunciation Practice: Trilled R
exercises.instructions: Listen and repeat the trilled რ [r]. Practice the tongue vibration.

questions.explanation: Practice vibrating your tongue tip against the alveolar ridge. Start with 'drrr' or 'prrr' if helpful, then isolate the trill.
Common word with trilled რ. Practice the smooth trill at the beginning.
Contains რ (though not word-initial). Practice the trill in the middle of the word.

exercises.title: Pronunciation Practice: Guttural Fricatives
exercises.instructions: Listen and repeat ღ [ɣ] and ხ [x]. Notice the difference between voiced and voiceless.

questions.explanation: Voiced guttural ღ [ɣ] - feel the vibration in your throat. Like a voiced version of clearing your throat.
Voiceless guttural ხ [x] - no vibration. Similar to German 'ch' in 'Bach' or Spanish 'j' in 'Jose'.
Common word with voiceless guttural ხ [x]. Practice the throat friction without vibration.

exercises.title: Complete Words with Difficult Sounds
exercises.instructions: Complete each word with the correct sound based on the pronunciation.

questions.question: Complete: __ა (what - uses trilled r):
questions.explanation: რა [ra] uses trilled რ [r]. One of the most common words in Georgian!

questions.question: Complete: __ამე (night - uses voiced guttural):
questions.explanation: ღამე [ɣame] uses voiced guttural ღ [ɣ]. Remember: voiced means you feel vibration!

questions.question: Complete: __არი (bull - uses voiceless guttural):
questions.explanation: ხარი [xari] uses voiceless guttural ხ [x]. No vibration - just throat friction.

exercises.title: Consonant Clusters
exercises.instructions: Answer questions about Georgian consonant clusters.

questions.question: Which word contains a complex consonant cluster?
questions.explanation: გრძელი [grdzeli] contains the cluster 'grdz' - four consonants in a row! Georgian is famous for complex clusters like this.

questions.question: What's the best strategy for practicing consonant clusters?

options.text: Start slow, pronounce each consonant separately, then speed up
Always say them as fast as possible
Only practice one consonant at a time

questions.explanation: Start slow and pronounce each consonant separately (gr-dz-eli), then gradually speed up until you can say it smoothly (grdzeli). This builds muscle memory!
